F75E9878A87548A9A8DF4B33BE6E37B8.description:
Understands explanations when concrete
objects and actions support the verbal
explanation, and phenomena are directly
observable (e.g., "When we mix colors, we
get a new color. See what color you get
when you mix yellow with blue.").

A8F6ECD9C9DD4A1CB9AB4DFFE619C347.description:
Able to act out simple roles (i.e., “Look, I
am a dog, ruff, ruff.”).

CB7791A855094D428603510033260EB9.description:
Identifies difference between fantasy and
reality with adult support and prompting.

0A7B16658DD743418D859C662CEB1EDB.description: Engages in pretend play and acts out roles i

73D00BD9A8F24757B634566B369A7AC7.description: Begins drawing in a more realistic manner, occasionally oscillating between realism and scribbling.

7ACEE333665A4351B30A9F9D1BAEA885.description: Develops generic symbols for repeated drawings of common objects like the sun, dog, and house.

293D9E0E432B4B7FA3A0096EAAB70DF7.description: Represents people, places, or things through drawings, movement, and three-dimensional objects.

6F2855C9B9F3461EBBC6BD5C656E779D.description: Begins to reference past knowledge to create an understanding of new information through pretend play (e.g., says, “This game is like the one we played in Ms. Kim’s class”).

95279883AAE54D849F1AA47CC5C146DF.description: Begins to understand how to use age-appropriate classroom materials with modeling and prompting. Follows adult direction and modeling for an assigned task (e.g., turns pages of a book with care, then puts the book back on the shelf with prompting).

A2D4804010524D45A2D40ECC6C4EA8C9.description: Begins to recognize where materials belong.

5ADC3990085E45EE8D7F4C891247FB93.description:
Begins to help with cleanup after
activities with prompting and adult
assistance.

7EAF70ABE3E94F83AB4F53C4444CF2F0.description: Demonstrates appropriate use of materials or belongings and respects those of others.

6611C7CD320E4234822735510557E330.description:
Engages with trusted adults during
transition with support and
encouragement.

5FB227E1FC5D40FB96606F6761C65DA7.description:
Demonstrates comfort with the transition
from home to the classroom environment
(e.g., begins to calm down quicker and
more frequently when parents leave).

426BBCBF78764642A8019A6514060AA1.description: Demonstrates the ability to adapt to new environments with appropriate behaviors with adult support.

1876A26AC3B84E37AC4D1026A6590691.description: Demonstrates the ability to stop an engaging activity to help clean up with adult support.

78657D0382D04AE083FF9DAD9DB60342.description: Moves from a preferred activity to a less preferable activity with adult support and assistance.

2AA401BBA4E94C7F8D93C26D2A247291.description: Responds to visual or auditory prompts and cues to transition to the next activity with adult support.

05436B34F72D4DBD98B1D657CF28021C.description: Demonstrates the ability to stop one activity and start

95F13EE29CC8441183F719F3241AFF8B.description: Begins to anticipate the next activity in the routine (i.e., asking, “Are we going outside?” during snack time).

8CC1C763D7F545CDA37D9807D1E6FE54.description: Behaves appropriately within the context of classroom routines (i.e., sits for brief periods during circle time or washes hands for lunchtime).

8A3E761FF57A420492A9C09CC5332D3D.description: Understanding and complying with classroom rules, routines and expectations

03C49B146A394B7996C6B75E799A12AE.description: Continues to learn simple alternatives to aggressive ways of dealing with conflicts (e.g., trades one doll for a desired one by saying, "You have THIS dolly, okay?").

75C6A96520964B9596E7C58F17EFC5EC.description: Seeks adults' help in resolving a conflict (e.g., goes to Dad and says, "Jacob took my truck!").

ED7BDD60A9EA40158A5ED54E2CC0DEAE.description: Accepts compromise when resolving conflicts if it is suggested by an adult (e.g., Mom says, "Jackson, you can use that swing as soon as Sheila has finished.").

D15E135871914B4D90DB1A0D98C5D7E4.description:
Begins to have real friendships, even
though he or she may not understand
the concept of friendship or that these
relationships may not last (e.g., says
“my best friends are Nathan, Sharon,
Enrique, Cassidy…” and all others in his
or her class).

C856EF9ED3F6491A8F7FA8E10B178B45.description: Attempts to give aid may not take into account the other child's characteristics or needs (e.g., offers a crying classmate his or her own stuffed animal, even though the child has another comfort object).

C420072654A54ABFA50200D8E0856053.description: Offers basic help to peers who are in need, upset, hurt, or angry (e.g., gives a hug, offers a comfort object, pats them, or says an encouraging word).

14AD11B58B59480BBAAB8312F61FFCF1.description:
Can adjust approach to a task to
resolve difficulties with adult help
(e.g., if teacher suggests the child
rotate a puzzle piece to find a better
fit).

20F41E259E3F4206936C5BD4AB6F0D88.description: Continues to stack cups or complete a simple puzzle unsuccessfully without an emotional outburst, with adult support.

E541EC0ECE2C46468F6E8688291FE90F.description: Insists upon putting on a coat independently, even though prior attempts have been unsuccessful.

3971E9482BC34C12968D455726B7BAA3.description:
Notes sense of accomplishment
when finishing a planned activity (i.e.
successfully drawing a figure).

C1449B13F49C4F5A890A1C2F901288F4.description: Keeps working to complete a task even if it is moderately difficult (e.g., persists with a somewhat challenging wooden puzzle).

09895822178B4A3484E04910492C617E.description: Persists with a wider variety of tasks, activities, and experiences with adult prompting.

43A93A07834E4A94BE1280340711E6FB.description: Persists in an activity from start to finish (completes a task) independently.

6C36E4B4430B42D7B4D6E836ABA253A2.description: Begins to independently select appropriate materials during specific activities (e.g., when presented with a painting project, gets red and green paint).

9F3718E1913C4A3EA43007C16C0BF0AA.description:
Chooses where to play during center
time.

3135C850C290492AB3316D246DFE2CAC.description: Begins to actively participate in classroom activities (i.e., answers questions or joins dramatic play).

6826FD1740FE4B16AE395F65EC3DDFB2.description: Independence in learning – plans and initiates projects.

6D6FCA0B7433480EBC0D8B53C2975399.description: Starts to demonstrate enthusiasm for new challenges and experiences.

E23F08BB83A741DC9870436E825D4A74.description: Continues to ask numerous questions, which are becoming more verbally complex (e.g., asks, "How do we get to Nana's house?").

700B6417657145A4860E9D0DA77B1953.description: Desire to learn – interest in challenges

A74B6815A2814C8D9CFF3EC128152403.description: Generates ideas with teachers and peers with adult modeling and support.

6B42769D29E749BAA143FEADF9BAEB17.description: Seeks experiences with new toys and materials (e.g., listens to stories, plays with friends at the water table, takes trips to the fire station).

3352308C53E44124977BED73536AE676.description: Begins to ask basic “wh” questions related to the environment (e.g., “Where is Sarah going?”).

97A7A5BD54EC40B7BF6C18583C021E59.description: Desire to learn – asks questions and seeks new information.

F9C579A2E64743E9B43A9C9ABD758459.description:
When faced with a problem, can slow
down and think through options with
support from an adult (e.g., “It looks
like someone is in your way. What
could you do to get him to move?”)

73FB54B9529A4BB1992AA0390AE8AACB.description:
After a conflict with another child, can
talk about other ways the problem
might have been resolved.

FC3668D1BC554F45B57983D95B55BA0F.description: Continues to become more flexible in problem-solving and thinking through alternatives (e.g., when trying to put on shoes, talks to self about what to do first. If the shoe won't easily go on one foot, he or she tries the other foot).

CBB37C08A6FA443DAD77585CAA0AFA88.description: Asks adults to solve or "fix" a problem.

D9DE7B627B0A4FCFB3EF321319D5A783.description: Employs a strategy to solve a problem with adult modeling, prompting, and support.

01A3F5CABA2E4A91B9B21497D08AEB42.description: Flexible problem solving-seeks multiple solutions to a question, task, or problem.

05A135C9775149EE903373E50CEF0B57.description:
Able to sort materials by two
different characteristics (e.g.,blocks
go here, dolls go here).

80734C2173C944E4B87D99918DD262AE.description:
Can recognize when making a
mistake and change approach with
adult help.

F9C077A2FD274E61B82C4CD2AA2BED76.description:
Can learn to follow different rules
in different contexts and can do so
with reminders (e.g., use indoor
voices indoors but not outdoors).

4890744619814745956961D8E8C5093A.description:
Can enjoy games with rules and
follow the rules some of the time.

93C38B543842496DB3A2078C729D892E.description: Can take on a character in pretend play and sustain this role consistently for approximately 5-10 minutes with adult modeling and support.

B5CDCABC926E4C76A39941AE49DEF5DC.description: Can flexibly apply rules to games and behavior

A654C7604E7A4D0DA7E549B81F349EE3.description:
Can enjoy success at simple memory
games tracking a few objects or
pictures.

E8AA37CE30674838A073123BE580424A.description:
Can put down a toy and remember its
location for a brief period of time.

45F656C19C02431CA0379931F5E7B215.description:
Can remember a response to a
teacher’s question long enough to
respond appropriately after waiting
for a turn during a short group
discussion.

C3FECD3EA07649C1890B5769FDA1C562.description:
Can hold two rules in mind long
enough to complete the tasks (i.e.,
“Throw your trash away, and then
put your lunchbox in your cubby).

B7F555020CDA4D7092118EB4AE6EF9E3.description:
Can consider two options and make
a choice when asked.

A3CE231480F9457D904EBFA6CF5154EA.description:
Can remember and talk about what
has just happened in a story and
what is happening now.

81C9CCEB0D54426C987072FDD22911C9.description: Demonstrate the ability to hold and manipulate information

1E83A8B31EB64DFB9C13B6B3D9B37220.description:
Can return to an earlier task after an
interruption, with adult reminders.

D0AE65E4A58F4837B5CC2D5465AC60BF.description: Remains on task during an activity set by the teacher for short periods of time despite distractions, though still may require prompting from an adult.

9F5D02A86478459C9463CC93EAC52429.description: Attentiveness – Resists distraction to maintain focus on tasks set by someone else

1C892E472D6A4B7488D3F3023AFB4FA4.description: Maintains focus on one activity for longer periods of time as long as the activity is age-appropriate and of interest (e.g., can repeatedly solve and dump out a wooden puzzle, even with other children playing in the background).

85049376437840F3B09196CACC9B3ED9.description: Attentiveness – Resists distraction to maintain focus on tasks of interest to the child

E78FCA16D7214CAD9008401997C2E0C5.description: Shows progress in resisting the impulse to harm self, others, or property in difficult situations or conflicts and uses language to express strong feelings instead (e.g., says, "I really, REALLY need that swing!"). May still fall apart under stress.

B6700F1DD3134D798CFAA3D7DAF4DACA.description: Refrains from emotional outbursts and unsafe behaviors.

B3B3844149A64F6AAA004823082CB511.description: Able to take turns with preferred toys with prompting from an adult.

0D14D097B1644F57B797F89C9A39CF35.description:
Can wait for a highly desired
food or object with adult
reminders (e.g., can wait to
eat the cupcake in reach
until the birthday song is
complete).

B3AD332B7EF540F19E245F8B3B9A21AB.description: Briefly able to wait for an object without grabbing. Can wait longer with adult support.

37576333ECE646AF9DCB2CC61E77E1C3.description:
Can enjoy games like Red Light,
Green Light that require waiting for
signal to do something with adult
support.

D9D7D183239240A29273048C8E4726EF.description:
May need to be reminded to stop a
habitual action when it is not
appropriate (e.g. continuing to go to
the bathroom for paper towels even
though they have been moved into
the classroom).

4191C01C153E4D98856F12D85798F2FC.description:
May remind other children to
control their impulses and follow
rules when not able to do so
oneself.

D4A352F4EA5643638BACCCE672AAD545.description: Developing the ability to control impulses during structured activities with adult support (i.e., resisting the impulse to call out before raising a hand during group time).

052B92C54B794C658F9F2EFE2C36B12D.description: Occasionally avoids imitating the negative behaviors of peers with prompting from an adult.

2B7965DE5DFF4DF9812D800B0D93B247.description: Approaches to Learning and Executive Functioning

780DB2C6284E4B4E958096703CC789B8.description: Continues to learn simple alternatives to aggressive ways of dealing with conflicts (i.e., trades one object for a desired one).

2426888F908842ACA4D077D0D5A95AB6.description: Seeks adults' help in resolving a conflict (i.e., goes to Dad and says, "Jacob took my truck!").

2F79D8E51C094280865D8BDB9986E649.description: Accepts compromise when resolving conflicts if suggested by an adult (e.g., Mom says, "Jackson, you can use that swing as soon as Sheila finishes her turn.").

03B8B76ED2044C8A9D9BE3A8F2E357BF.description:
Identifies when a peer is not given
the same instructions or structure
(e.g., “Katie gets to go into the block
center.”)

097514792D2A4F0D8FCB69852A8F4C1F.description:
Begins to recognize differences or
similarities between self as
compared to others (i.e., children
with disabilities, gender, hair color,
etc.).

15C051173CEA449C937D82E28FBE66AC.description: Recognizes differences or similarities between self as compared to others

B6DF95E6521643EC8AF02A45E2D73246.description:
Begins to understand the concept
of sharing with adult modeling and
support.

F2669ECE7EB14D8D93FEA94CB07D6F69.description:
Plays alongside other children (i.e.,
dramatic play, block table).

27D265BFB5A4476CA69FC8F6BACB9095.description: Plays or works with others cooperatively

2E75B9FD716F453FBC357627B87C1C00.description:
Recognizes when someone needs
help, but may not respond every
time.

A30728DD757D4C5AAE9CD0A499E6EDD7.description:
Begins to express emotions through
non-verbal cues with adult modeling
and support (i.e., body language,
facial expressions, crosses arms, and
frowns).

74B185D073F14667974AD3F5F396B4FA.description:
Identifies basic feelings (i.e. sad,
mad, happy).

A87BBF3DB6C64581A801E9C7EA491BF0.description: Expresses, understands, and responds to feelings(emotions) of others

56D80E4725904620B290A08FF5413B34.description:
Recognizes the appropriate place for
 items(e.g., their assigned seat, rest spot,
etc.).

D0576870F9074DA28DE5B6EC918F6B6E.description:
Begins to independently select
appropriate materials during specific
activities (i.e. when presented with a
painting project gets red and green paint.)

91D611980C6C4FD6A3B4E2A97AE0EDD9.description:
Chooses where to play during
 center time.

74791A74E90749D5A2B78824FE9C6F69.description:
Begins to actively participate in
classroom activities (i.e., answers
questions or joins dramatic play).

866F0F902B9940ACB893D2DD6D8D7668.description: Demonstrates independence in a range of routines and tasks
